title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system and protection of dependent privacy. Congress aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while ensuring privacy protection. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Treasury Secretary within 180 days of enactment. Employers can report essential coverage details for full-time employees through this system. The Act mandates a voluntary prospective reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for full-time employees, including coverage for dependents, spouses, part-time employees, minimum value requirements, and affordability safe harbors. The Act mandates a voluntary prospective reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for full-time employees, including coverage availability, waiting periods, and access to information by Exchanges and the IRS for eligibility determinations. The system created under the Act includes processes for eligibility determinations, follow-up with employers for necessary information, and timely updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub. The system created under the Act includes processes for eligibility determinations and timely updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub. Employers providing prospective reporting meeting certain requirements are exempt from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employers may use third parties for filing without affecting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code. Employers are notified by Exchanges about employee enrollments in qualified health plans. Each Exchange notifies employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan through the Exchange, without affecting the employer's liability under the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs for dependents if not collected before January 1, 2014. SEC. 5 relates to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consent has been given previously. Similarly, Section 6055(c) is amended to allow electronic delivery of health insurance coverage statements if prior consent for electronic health information has been given. The amendments made by this section allow electronic delivery of statements if prior consent for electronic health information has been given. Effective December 31, 2015. The amendments allow electronic delivery of statements with prior consent for electronic health information. Effective December 31, 2015. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding employee eligibility for tax credits and subsidies from 2014 to 2016. The study will evaluate the process of developing and sending notification forms to employers under the Affordable Care Act, including the adequacy of information provided, the number and timing of notifications, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges faced, and recommendations for improvement. The study will assess the notification process to employers under the Affordable Care Act, including challenges, recommendations, and the establishment of an appeals process by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will conduct a study evaluating the prospective reporting system established under section 3, focusing on information accuracy, employer participation, and implementation challenges. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan if eligibility for subsidies is redetermined annually, considering changes in premiums, Federal poverty level, and income data. If the marketplace does not follow the specified processes, reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed until current income information is provided. The marketplace may not automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan with subsidies until current income information is provided for redetermination. This aligns with guidance for annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments issued by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services in 2015. The marketplace must ensure that enrollees maintain authorization for disclosure of information, provide updated income details annually, and receive timely notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange under the Affordable Care Act.
